transcript.content: Uhh, It's the Best Of, you've been voting in all week, sending your emails, so here's the clips that you wanted.
Karl Pilkington, in the chair now. The, um, ah, the talked about, the acclaimed... Educating Ricky.
Right well, just in case anyone's new, doesn't normally listen...
Uh, do a bit of research in the week. Find stuff- news, history, anything that's interesting.
Ummm, three stories, I give them a nice little headline, you take your pick...
Between now and 3 you're gonna learn three things, yeah?
The headlines are, ummm, 'Albino buying one of them'.
'Chi-cken you believe it?' Well, it's your choice Rick.
Well I'm gonna go for Hippopota-nuse.

Right, well this one, it's uh- i- I'm not gonna take the credit here, I heard Christian talking about this on Breakfast right, 'cause it's a good good, uhh, good story that happened. Umm, basically, I don't know if I told you about it last week when we were having our spaghetti. But ummm...
(laughing) I know what it is! I know what this is.
Circus going on somewhere, I think it was in America. And umm...
Is that present day, or old times?
I'm talking, like, in the last three weeks.
Right, uhh, little midget, uh, circus, really packed out show, people are loving it. Umm-
(laughing) Right, Steve! You'll ask the same question I did, I know.
So umm, so this little- little midget jumping up and down on a trampoline.
(laughing) What sort of circus is this?!
I'd pay good money to see it!
Everyone- everyone's clapping, and he's getting carried away, uhh-
'Cause he can't believe his luck, he can't believe- they're loving it. "I didn't know they'd like a little person on a trampoline, but they love me!"
But you know what it's like when, uhh, if there's a crowd of people sort of encer- couraging you to, sort of, go higher and stuff.
And I'm sure he knew he was g- it was getting out of hand.

But he was jumping and he was coming down and they're all going "Higher!" and he's going really high in the air, right. So he's- he's doing this, crowd are clapping. There's a hippo, right, just sat next to
The trampoline, getting ready to come on and do his act.
Oh right, I thought he was in the audience.
(laughing) This hippo getting ready to do his act, Steve!
What do you mean, "He's sitting by the trampoline waiting to do his act"!?
Why doesn't he sit in the dressing room and they go, (knocking) "Five minutes!"
So anyway right. So the hippo's there, uhh.
He's getting annoyed, is he? Cause this- cause the midget's eating into his time?
This is really annoying. They're going to be... ah no.
He's thinking, he's already done the trampoline, my pogo stick act is never gonna work!
Yeah go on, so there's a hippo waiting, eh- this, this- see it's a great story and I just know he embellishes it or he gets slightly wrong, go on.
So there's a midget jumping up and down...
The midget's loving it, can't believe his luck. Although we think- you think he probably knows he's dicing with danger.
They're all saying "Higher, higher", he gives it one big, like, heavy sort of landing on the trampoline, goes really high. But, goes off at a funny angle...
Yeah? Umm, and sort of flies at-
Ricky bursts out laughing, then Steve
Flies off at a funny angle...
Crowd are clapping, thinking "That's why the hippo was waiting there".
Steve laughs louder, Ricky joins him

But n- nooo, maybe the- there was an accident in a, uhh, a circus with a midget and a hippo eat him, but at no point was this hippo waiting to go on going "Come on", the midget flew off at a hypotenuse, and landed in the hippo's mouth and was swallowed whole!
This is- this is what you embellished- that is great, and what's that-
I have to say though, Rick, when I heard: midget, trampoline, hippot- hippopotamus, I was thinking 'accident waiting to happen'.
It is uh, that- that- that- you should never put those three together.
It's a- it's a recipe for disaster-
Everyone knows that. "Midget, trampoline, hippopotamus? Are you mental?!"
You know when he told me it, he said "And the midget", he didn't mention the hippopotamus, and he said "the midget went higher and higher, and soon he fell off, and the Hippo eat him."
And I said "Sorry? What was the hippo doing there?" He went "It's a circus."
I've never heard of a circus having a hippo?!
What can they do? You can't train them, can you?
You can't have a hippo in a circus! You're not thinking of Zippo?
He did- he- no ye no- an- and- It wasn't, it wasn't, it wasn't some sort of- where Zippo was 'eating a midget' and it's some sort of horrible sexual act?
No it was defin- I heard it on Breakfast, right? And, definitely-
No, it's definitely fact, then, it's definitely truth.
Yeah, okay, right, okay, good. Uhh, let's play a record then.
104.9, I'm Ricky Gervais, uh, with me Stephen Merchant-
Uh, it's the best-of. You've been voting in all week, sending your emails, so here's the clips that you wanted.
We- we- me and Karl went out, right? Um, and uhh, uh with, um, me and Jane and Karl and Johnny and Gigi, wasn't it?
But we're walking down the street. Karl was there though and he can back me up on this. Um, we'd had a curry, we're walking back, and uhh, this little funny homeless fella, didn't he?
He, er- oh I gotta tell it before-fore I go "didn't he?"

He came up to me, right? And he recognized me. And he came up to me and he went - he went, "Oh!" He said, "I've just nicked one of your DVDs from HMV." And he shook my hand. He was so happy with it. And I went, "Right. Excellent." He went, "All I did was I just swing the bag over the top. Like that, when I'm going out." And he had a bag full of DVDs, didn't he? And he was - he was so pleased to tell me he'd stole it. Isn't that great?
He said - he said, "They're going like hotcakes."
He said they're going - of course they are! I know.
We get paid for them though, don't we?
So, he - not the stolen ones.
No! What do you mean? Did you sign them for him?
You idiot. What, so um - he just nicked five -
And you said he was homeless, was he?
Well I - I - he - don't know. Maybe.
Surely, how would he have seen the show? He just walked past Currys one - one morning.
Seen the trailer for it, thought, "Mmm, interesting."
I don't know if he was homeless, I didn't - I didn't go into his home life.
Sure. You shook his hand though, and -
But he's - he made Karl look
Smart, do you know what I mean?
So uh - how does he sell them? Where does he sell them? Does he go up to people going, "Do you want an Office DVD? They're not nicked."
"No, no, no, no, no." "They still got the tags on them."
Well, it's like those people who um - you - those cab drivers that you often meet at sort of 3:00 in the morning who've just got a car.
And just went out with a car.
And just - "I'll - I'll pick people up and charge them."

I said to him, "Uh" - a guy just pulled up. I said - he said - I was in like kind of East London, I'm going back to North London. I said, "Uh, yeah, going to uh, Swiss Cottage." He went, "Sure. Hop in." We set off. He went, "Do you know the way?"

I said, "Well, not really, no. I thought - I thought you'd know, wouldn't you? You're a cabbie, aren't you?" He went, "No, don't really know the way there." I said - I said, "Have you got an A to Z?" He went, "No." I thought, "Well if you're going to go out just on the - you know, just winging it as a cab driver" -
Two things: take a map and a torch. He didn't have either. He said, "Well, I'll probably get to Camden." I said, " Right, I'll direct you from there."
Drove on for about five minutes, making conversation. About five minutes later, he went, "Do you know the way to Camden?"
"I thought you knew the way to Camden!" "I don't really know the way, I thought I did."

Exactly and that's - I can't - I don't know who's got that sort of time on their hands that they just think, "It's 3:00 in the morning. I'm at a loose end. I think I'll go out doing a bit of cabbing."
'Cause your dad was a cabbie, wasn't he?
Yeah, he was, yeah. Couldn't stand it, but it's - it's good money.
He was a - he wasn't like a Chancellor -
What was - what was he - what was he doing when he put that little
That was - that was part of the cab company thing. He had to do like a charity event once a year and he did it one year. Never asked him again.
Tell the story again, I know you told me but -
No, I'd rather not because we got -
Because we got a few, sort of, uh, complaints about it.
Why? Why'd you get complaints about it?
Because - because he put a kid in a bin and it's not the thing to do.
But we could use it as a sort of sobering lesson for people.
Yeah. Tell it like a - tell it like a - you know, don't - "You shouldn't do it."
Nah, it's - it's - yeah, but that's how I did it last time, but people still didn't like it. All the stuff I tell you, I don't - you know, we don't take the mickey out of people on purpose.
And that goes on in life.
Me dad was saying that in hospital though. D'you know how he's in hospital?
You know, he did some jokes about old people and that, and he said "at the end of the day, if something makes you laugh it's funny, d'you know what I mean?
So, what are you meant to do?
But being laughed at isn't as good for you, is it?
No, but there's probably more people laughing at one person so if you balance it out, there's only one person who's upset and a bunch of people laughing.
That's genius! Give me an example of that, give me an example-
As he talks and the people listening.
(laughing) Yeah, yeah. No, give a little example of like- so I- I- y'know.
I c- well I can't because again, that's what I'm saying. I can't tell you the story...
...'cause they might be someone out there who... m- this person might even be listening and think, "I forgot about that and you brought it all back to me again."
S-So, I'd prefer to leave it but I think people know wh-
Why did he put him in the bin in the first place?
Because he was getting out of hand.
You see, I can't explain without-
I'd prefer to... to leave it, honestly.
Would- wha- what was he doing, was he annoying him?
He was annoying me dad and the other people in the cab.
And he thought, "How can I deal with this before it gets too out of hand?"
He pulled over and put the lad in a wheelie bin.
XFM 104.9, uh, Ricky and I are on holiday, obviously it's Christmas time but Karl is here in the studio, he's pressing buttons, alright Karl?
What d'you make of the first genetically modified baby?
D'you- d'you know w-what did they do? What-
Let me see what it says here, it says uhh
Well isn't it just choosing ch-choosing the , y'know,

Well this is the- this is the- this is the concern, isn't it? That in the future you'll be able to decide, uh, whether it's a boy or a girl. What- how intelligent it is, what it looks like, is it handsome, is it ugly- obviously no one would choose an ugly baby, and so on and so on and so on. And so, it means that, you know, w-where will it lead, where will it end Karl? Are you concerned?
I've thought about this a lot because-
What will us three look like in the future? If they're being, you know, genetically modified beautiful people, what will be- we be like? How will we be considered in society?
That's true, yeah. But we've talked about this before, haven't we? About, uh, the cloning thing...

But, umm, I don't think it matters because, at the end of the day, right, you might look like some other kid, but it's the way you've br- that you're brought up that will change your features, and the way you are. You know, your personality-
If you lie you get a long nose, don't you.
Well no, but listen right, 'cause I remember when whe-when we, you know, I was growing up on this estate-
This is gonna be good, go on.
No, no it's not. It's just a- an example of how this doesn't work...
...so- so we don't need to worry sort of thing, right?
So, I'm growing up on this estate, and there was uhhh, there was this woman about four houses down, right.
Oh, God no! Right but, she had a baby-
Why? Well tell me about her first, I'm interested in this woman, why was she-
She look like Bernard Manning in a dress?
I mean I didn't grow up in a posh house or anything...
...and I'm not- I'm not saying that if you live in a bit of a rough house...
Look like Tony Green with a fag on?
They didn't clean up much, right?
Which- even if you've not got a lot of money, you can still...
A kid used to take a horse into the house.
Hah, whoa whoa whoa whoa whoa whoa whoa whoa whoa.
... hold on, yeah. Woah Neddy, whoa Neddy! What do you mean, "A kid used to take a horse into the house"?
Where did he get a horse?
Must have nicked it from somewhere.
"Uh Sir, you seen a horse aro-?" "Nope!"
(laughing) What, is that from outside the saloon around the corner?
(laughing) Yeah, was it just tied up with a bit of leath- (trails off laughing)
Did Big Jake come a-looking for it?
Now, sorry, let me get this- this was before the
(laughing) Where did he get a horse from?! What d'you mean, "He must have nicked it"?! His mum said, "Where d'you get that from?" "I bought it." "Alright then, but keep it out the kitchen!"
"I don't want you going cattlin' rustlin'!"
Oh! Where did he get a horse from, Karl?
And how long did he have it for?
Was he leading it or riding it? "Mum, open the door I can't stop!"
(laughing) "I can't stop it! Open the patio door as well I'll be-"
"Looks like we got us a runaway!" What do you mean?!
I don't know. But the thing is, they couldn't afford to buy one 'cause they're not cheap, so I'm just guessing. Maybe that's wrong of me. But I-I think-
That's why the family didn't have any money, they'd spent it on the horse!
No I think- that's what I'm saying;
I don't think they would have bought it. So anyway-
Yeah it's wise to whisper, Karl, in case they're listening.
They could be in the room next door.
It's not buying it, it's keeping it as well! Oh!
So I- so I was like in the car with me dad, coming to the avenue and you used to have to drive down it to turn round...
...And uh- and, you know, sort of go back to w- to our house.
You had the traditional method of transport, yeah.
And uh... the horse was in the lounge.
And when I- when I was doing- ah- d- I tried to earn meself some money once buy flogging little flowers in- in plastic cups.
...genius, he just keeps coming! What d'you mean 'you tried to flog little flowers'? What do you mean?!
Well... that's not the story, that's not the story!
Wait, wait wait wait wait wait wait, let's play a record, let's play a record...
Wait a minute, wait a minute!
...'cause this story's just gonna unravel and unravel...
...it's gonna go on for hours, let's play a track, Karl-
It gets deeper and deeper! It's like an onion, isn't it?
Yeah come on, Karl. You've- we've created a whole world here where there's a man living with a horse!
Just walking around the lounge! I just-
I mean I come from the West Country and never heard anything like that!
I just- I just think of a big, sort of like,
Orange carpet and it's got- a vr- a rediffusion telly and this horse going, "I'm fed up in here."
"I am not taking the rubbish out again!"
Right, play a record. Let's have, uh, Velvet Underground we got that lived up have we?
Yeah, the classic from the first album, uhh, 'I'm Waiting For The Man'. Let's come back to the horse in the settee.
"Little flowers in pots." What do you mean? Ahh.
The Velvet Underground, Nico - I'm Waiting For The Man
Velvet Underground and Nico which apparently peaked at a disappointing 171 in the US charts...
...and that's obviously Lou Reed- The Velvet Underground and, uh, 'Waiting For The Man'.
Yeah, great track. So, we were talking, uh, we were doing White Van Man. And, uh, we got on to uh, um, to genetically-
We got on to, uh, genetically modified babies, but somehow we-
And then Karl started telling a story about someone with a horse, and then he got on to- he was trying to make money selling flowers. Just do the flowers briefly.
Well hang on, I just wanna recap slightly. So there was a family and, who had the horse in the family?
'Cause you lived on a h- an estate in Manchester
So the mother was a right pig, apparently. I don't know where that's...
Well, you don't need to go that far.
But what I'm trying to do is, like, make a picture for you so you understand...
And what a picture it is.
Who did she look like? Who did she look like?
Okay. I knew you were gonna say that. I knew it was gonna be Pauline. Did she have any tats? Did she have any tattoos?
I never got that close to her.
So, and so, who had the horse? Was this her son or her husband?
Her daughter had stolen a horse?
Yeah. From... I don't know where. There was... I think there was some stables down the road or something.
And they kept the horse in the house with them?
They kept it in the house. They didn't have it for long.
Sorry, and you said you were in the house one day and you saw the horse in there?

No, what happened was, um, they did this thing at school about raising money for charity, right? For some local charity. And they said you can do anything to raise money and they came out with all these ideas and I thought that's good.
But forget... well, I dunno. I thought 'forget the charity'. I'm the charity here.
Yeah, it's just a good money-making... (laughing) You're a charity?
So, I asked me mam for some - she used to have a lot of flowers round the house.
I said, 'Can I just take some snippings of them? And I'll go and buy some plastic cups?' And uh, got some soil out the garden, planted the bits of plants in them.
Did you just cut... you didn't just cut them and stick them in soil did you?
But I think people sort of thought, 'Well, good on him for trying.' But anyway, so I went round to theirs, because I thought, 'Their house could do with a bit of colour and stuff.'
Because it's a bit rough. So as I went...
The horse went, 'Thank God for that, breakfast! They've been feeding me Kit E Kat."
So I got up to the door, and they opened the door, and it was one of them houses where... no carpet.
(laughing) Yeah... a horse in the living room.
And the horse was walking round the living room. And it looked quite happy and everything, because I always say that about animals, right?
Well, think about it, right? If you were a horse, where would you rather be - in a little wooden hut with a load of hay, or in, like, a house with a...
No, but I was saying this the other day...
I was walking through London the other day...
Walking through London with Suzanne, right?
And do you know how, like, homeless people always have dogs?
And she said, 'Ooh, I hope she looks after it.' And I said, 'They've got... that dog is happier than most dogs.'
Because people always walk past and give it a pat on the head.
With it's owner all the time.
It's out in the open, it's not locked up in a house.
It doesn't eat, but other than that.
No, it does eat, though! They're always alright. So that's what I was saying, I think this horse was doing alright for itself.
(laughing) Well, not many horses have got their own house, for a start. Yeah.
So anyway, this family, who's a bit... what were we talking about? It was about cloning...
Genetically modified kids and all that stuff, yeah.
Right, now, what I'm saying is, you could say... you know, right Steve, you could have a baby and Ricky could see it and say, 'God, I want one that looks like that.'
So you take it to the doctor's. And I dunno what they do with it, they inject it with something or whatever.

And, uh, get a little baby and there it is. It looks the same. Now the thing is: You separate. You both go off and do your own things. Right. Now, you look at Ste- Steven, this is. You look after your baby.
You treat it well. You give it good food and that.
All the vitamins and stuff. Ricky just gives it cheese. Right.
Then it changes its looks. It goes a bit fat. You know, it gets tired easily and that sort of thing. Now, when this family-
Why am I just feeding a baby cheese?

Right, this, this, um, this, this, this family who had a horse in the g- in the, you know, in their house. They had a, a little baby. And me mam went round and said, "You're not gonna believe this but it's a beautiful looking baby". Right. And I was like, "Well, you know". And, uh, the weird thing is it was a good looking kid. But as time went on they didn't really look after it, and I'm not
Saying like abusing it but it used to run around. It used to play out til like ten at night.
Uh, it used to chase cars.
It used to chase cars! What sort of kid chases cars?!
Oh, God! Was it called Rover?
Now, the weird thing is it was a good looking kid but as time went on and all that, like, not eating properly and its hair was all
It's not Liam Gallagher is it?
And chasing cars and that and it became an ugly kid.
And that's- that's what I'm saying, right. You can cl- you can clone all you like but at the end of the day it's how you're brought up.
That was a hell of a point!
I'm Ricky Gervais. With me, Steve and Karl. Karl, why have you got a headache? You got a headache?
Stressful cos the move's- move's on this, uh, this week.
Oh by the way, uh, the Xfm listeners came round to me house and bought the, uh, futon and table.
Quite normal. They were well happy.
Couldn't believe their luck with it.
What do you mean, 'quite normal'? What do you mean, 'quite normal'?
Well it's always a bit scared init, getting, getting people round.
And were they excited to see you? Could they- I mean they were- You know, could you tell that they were pretty pleased to see you?
No I don't think so. I mean, you know-
Yeah but I- The- the fella sort of, I mean they brought their whole family round. Which was a bit odd.
Well it's not often they get the chance to, to visit a living freak.
Anyway. Anyway, they were- they were nice. They were nice.

And you're moving now are ya? He said- he phoned me up today. You know it was absolutely tipping it down. He had to cycle in cos he said cos of the move he doesn't wanna leave his bike round there. Right, and he said
Uhhh... Suzanne- oh, I can't say this in case he's listening, can I?
(laughing) He sa- he said Suzanne's hired the oldest removal man in London!

...We've booked him- we've booked him 'cause everyone else happened to be booked out but this fella's free, right? So he called up this morning and I've never spoke to him but he was on the phone. He sounded about ninety.
Karl thinks that he's gonna have to do all the work!
And the- and the thing is-
We- well, h- he seemed to be cheap.
He- all he wanted some Werther Originals!
Right listen. It seemed to be cheap because it's £50 an hour. But how-
But how long is it gonna take him?
Ricky continues laughing and bangs on table
So when's the move on then? When's he actually...
On what- he's coming r- he came round today to bring some empty boxes and he was struggling with them.
Ricky and Steve laugh, then Ricky coughs
So uhh, i- it actually happens on Wednesday.
I woke up this morning, yeah?
It's not a blues song. And, uh, I turned my phone on and it- it was from Karl and it went: "Forget it, I've made my mind up." And thought...
What is that? And phoned him-
Yeah. I went, "Karl, what is it?" He went, "Ah no, it's about the text I sent you last night." I went, "Well what- what was it, I just got this text." He went, "Ah. Ohh,
I was just wondering, I said I was thinking last night." He said, "Supposing you had to have your hands removed."

And the doctor said, "Well... you can either have 'em stay like that with stumps or I can sew feet there. What would you have?" And I was bleary-eyed and I went, "The stumps." He went, "Yep." I went, "Alright?" He went, "Yep." And th-
And then what was his follow-up

And then I got the text that was obviously before it, and it went- and it was like quite serious, "What- what would you do, if a surgeon had to remove your hands, would you have stumps or the feet?" Right? Now the way, uh- when I said, "He's made his mind up" and I went, "The stumps?" He went, "Yep." I think secretly he decided on the feet.
But was too embarrassed to tell me.
There was a little... little bit of 'what would you do?' Cause it's- it, last night-
But why did you think of this?! Why did you think of this?
You start thinking bizarre surgery devices!
I'll- I'll tell you know, right, I'll let you in to me little mind, right? Last night, I, um, I had some beans on toast, right? She's-
She was away, so you had some beans on toast, you went wild!

Right? Now, I was stood up, I live on like a- on a high street, right? So I'm- I'm washing up, I'm looking out the window. First thing that had me attention is; I can- I can look in to other people's flats, right?
And it was weird how all these different lives were going on; I was watching 'em, and everybody had the telly
On and was watching Volcano, right, which was on last night.
And I thought, "Oh, tha- that's weird." Right? I can see 'em all watching it, and there was like a little Chinese lad who was dancing around in some underpants.
And then there's a little old woman who lives downstairs who was reading a book, and she's always reading a book every night and it's like, "I have a better life than her."
There's like some sort of bouncer who's always ready to go out, late at night...
... with all the black on, he looks like a bouncer. So I was watching all this life going on I thought...
Did you witness a murder while you were doing it?
It was like, it was like that sort of Slither film where that bloke had loads of tellys watching peoples lives.

So that was going on in my mind and then I was washing up and I picked up the plate and I thought it's amazing innit the human body. The way you can just sort of, you know, "I wanna pick that up" and you do.
And the way your hands work, right, you've got five little digits but it's just the right amount to-
To do what you've gotta do? Right? So so I'm washin-
Ricky interrupts and bursts out laughing

Sorry Karl, stop, "it's just the right amount" might be one of the most genius things I've ever heard said. I would love David Attenborough to phone you up and say "Karl how do i word this, about the evolution of the mammalian front limb?", "well just say it's the right amount"
It is. Of course it is.
One extra would get in the way and one less would make it just that little bit more tricky when picking up a bit of a slippery dish.
So then I was thinking, alright, imagine like going the doctors and they say "yeah everything's alright, your 'earts good and everything but"
Your arts good? What your Lowrys or?
"Your heart, your heart, your in good form and what have you, it's good news, I had Jono in earlier, he's not looking good"
"But you're alright but your hands need to come off"
Right, blimey, that's bad luck. I'd get a second opinion initially.
"But a bit of good news, I've got a nice pair of feet I can sort you out with"
He puts them on, and then I was thinking right first of all: washing up what would that be like?
That would be tricky. And then the second thing was it would probably ruin the sort of shape of your jumper.
Because you'd have to keep putting your feet through there.
And then I thought but I could still cycle in to work-
Well that's what I was thinking, I thought, I could still cycle because I could balance.
And then I thought but the only thing is I probably couldn't pull the brakes.
Because of the little short things.
And then like you I thought but then again you're running in half time. So that's what was going on last night.
That's what I was thinking about.
Well, how long does it take to wash up?
Right, because I imagine you just being there for like, all night.
How long did the little Chinese fella dance for in his pants?
Last night he was at it for like 10 minutes. And his girlfriend never sits in the same room as him, she's always sat in the bedroom-
She's going "you dance in pants again I'm going next door"
Well she was in the bedroom, she's always in the bedroom sat on the floor, on the mobile phone
Yeah, all the time. It's weird how peoples lives are just like, it is like that Groundhog Day thing, it's like, he's jumping about in his underpants, the old woman's sat there reading a book.
And that's what got me thinking about my life-
Are you sure she's not dead?

See the-tha- Karl, that's the most interesting thing, if it's true that you've come up with.
Right, okay. And so, what's-what's-you- so they sell the rope?
They sell the rope and it's money for a rope.
Meaning like, you know, "God, it's easy to make money that- all I have to do is cut it up and sell it."
: Right, listen. We've-we're really tight, we haven't even got time for the last track. We've got an ad break and we gotta give out.
Okay, give the answers then this is--
--so, Steve do you wanna pick a winner?
Uh I've got a winner when you give us the answers.
Okay, so the first clue was uh, 'That Army as got some well nice trenches.'
Erm the second one, 'The top of them curtains are wrecked or the material is worn.' 'HV.' That's--
Oh, he got a phone call. For-a woman saying that 'I haven't heard it,' and she went- she was- he was talking to her off-air and she went--
What is it? Uhh, soandsoso, therewascurtains, she went, "Oh right", said, "You know the thing around the top of the, uh, curtain is a pelmet, not a valence" and he went... cut her off.
Yeah but, my auntie's always making valences on everything, I'll tell you about that next week. Right? Right?
I'm looking forward to that story.
Is this the one that farted for five minutes?
Right, so, we'll talk about that. Uhh, "I was in Texas, I tripped up, I landed on me knees in a puddle." 'W.H.'
We've got Pete, Katherine and Laura in Newcastle-upon-Tyne, their listening online, I assume, and uh...

They're gonna get those great prizes, and remember they've got loads of stuff, they've got, uh, the DVD here, they've got Linda Green, got Stone Roses, they've got another compilation, and Executive Decision.
Where did you read about Brian Blessed? Is it actually true, or have you just libelled someone else-
No it was a- it was an interview, with him in it, talking about it.
Come on! What did he say?!
He said "I c- I climbed Everest and, uh, it played havoc with me belly." Let's talk about it next week.
